subject: Add crypto Erase to eStorageD.
commitMessage:
Add crypto Erase to eStorageD.

The goal is to erase the keys that are used to decrypt the drive. After
the keys are erased it will not be possible to decrypt the drive, even
if the password can be recalled. The data is forever inaccessible.

Testing:

$ systemctl stop emmc.service

$ /eStoraged -b /dev/mmcblk0 &

$ busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume FormatLuks ays 3 1 2 3 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.FilesystemType.ext4

$ busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Lock

$ busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Erase s xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.EraseMethod.CryptoErase

$ busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Unlock ay 3 1 2 3
Call failed: The operation failed internally.

Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>
Change-Id: I3221e82a92c1b555e2379b19c9e1d5b6e4b02f9b

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 59dffa63af63ac1021f372e4505fb8c1b9084906
Why is this needed? Shouldn't you just wipe all keyslots?

that can be done. but it requires searching though all many possible keyslots and deleting each valid keyslot. 

example : https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/main/src/cryptenroll/cryptenroll-wipe.c#L426


Let me know if you see a better function in the API to use. I looked and this is the best thing I found.

I am searching though all of them.
like https://gitlab.com/cryptsetup/cryptsetup/-/blob/master/src/cryptsetup.c#L1538
Thanks for taking the time to look this over
nit: add a blank line between the namespace and the include.
done, last time I added the empty line between the class and the open brace
Just for my own information, what happens if you call this function on a keyslot with some other status?
It prints "I can't delete this :(" and returns and error.
It probably makes sense to put these test cases in their own file. To make that work, you'll need to put the MockCryptsetupInterface class in its own header file.

make sense. I just did not want to do it if you were not onboard.
Done

Is there a reason you're doing a >= comparison?

I think you should use Eq, instead.

that is funny oversight. It was comparing the pointers and failing, but when I switched to Ge, the new pointer was always greater then and passing.

Switched to StrEq, after I figured it out.
Is this function supposed to return CRYPT_SLOT_INVALID for every keyslot? If so, you should use WillRepeatedly in this case.
sure, I will also increase the number of slots, so we validate the looping.
Thanks for taking a look at this.

It is like that upstream. 
https://gitlab.com/cryptsetup/cryptsetup/blob/master/lib/libcryptsetup.h#L1744
I will add a PR to never ending todo list
done
I wouldn't normally expect the constructor itself to do the erase operation. Maybe sync up with Brandon and/or William about whether the crypto erase should be moved to another member function.

I moved it to a doErase member function.
Let me know if there is anything else I need to do.
Looks like you're not using this
Can this be set to eStoraged_headers instead of a relative path?

no, it fails with "Arguments must be strings" for the include_directories.
We could create "test_eStoraged_headers" at the top level messon, so the call would looks like.
> test_eStoraged_headers = include_directories('include', 'src/test/include')

Hmm, yeah that'd be fine with me.

Since there's only one test header file, it might also be okay to put estoraged_test.hpp in src/test/, same place as the *_test.cpp files, so you wouldn't have to bother with this.
I would rather not mix testing headers with binary headers. (in a year it will will be a real task to separate again, and eventually someone will care)

Bradon kim (in the top level meson)
>I'm guessing this would only be useful for tests within src/test, would it make sense for this to go to src/test/meson.build?

Ideally we would just add a headerfile to the existing eStoraged_headers. Or Maybe I can create a new set of include dirs and use two different include dirs on line 22
Yes, I think your last option makes the most sense imo
I think this parameter should still be in the constructor.

It is only used in the doErase method, and it would require adding a member variable to the class to hold the value.

It can be done, but can you help me understand why it should be in the constructor?

I think the cryptsetupInterface is more a property of the class. If someone adds more member functions to this class (e.g. a function to erase a specific keyslot, or a function to erase a keyslot that matches a particular password), those functions would probably need to use the same cryptsetupInterface.
Looks like you have a lot of includes that aren't being used, but other than that, it looks good.

Yeah, imho the goal should be adding a tool called iwyu to the docker test as a option.
That would automatically identify files that need to be includes, and should not be included. But in the short term I did it manually
not needed? Some of the other includes in this file probably aren't needed, either
Are any of these headers necessary?
No name for the parameter variable? It looks like it's supposed to be type
Just realized, do we even use this anymore since we don't generate the dbus headers?
I'm guessing this would only be useful for tests within src/test, would it make sense for this to go to src/test/meson.build?

It was here and we moved it to avoid the relative path.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/50394/7..11/src/test/meson.build#b12

I will open re open wedigs comment when it was there.

Oh, I see what's going on.

I feel we should probably have a different include_directories for "include" defined here, and a test one at the test meson.build then use both at the test meson.build.

Question: Will this always be CRYPT_LUKS2? or would there be time when it's not (as in, should we need to worry about having to pass this in as a parameter?). I think we use it in other places already so I'm guessing we have a design decision to only use this

I don't know if an official desion has been made.

Wedig uses it:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/50394/11/src/estoraged.cpp#b215

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/50394/11/src/estoraged.cpp#b178

I felt it would be unseemly for me to make it configurable while Wedigs work uses it directly. We can make it a build time variable in another CL?
Yeah we can have a discussion when he's back and in another CL

sounds good. We will align with wedig.

Personally, I think LUKS2 hard coded will be fine until someone wants to use another crypt type. But if another/better crypt type appears we might switch everything to it.
Is 0 key slot an invalid number of keyslots? Technically, it is valid (as in, it's not a negative number to indicate an error) but we don't want a 0 keyslot I guess?

yeah, if we have zero keyslots, that means the device is already ran cryptoErase.
So I thought it might be better to fail, but maybe it is better to not fail.
Changed.

Oh I see. It is currently exiting gracefully without doing anything instead (due to for loop condition below.

I'm not sure what the proper behavior is here. We could have a different if case here for 0 specifically if you'd like to notify the users that it didn't do anything maybe? with a warning message, but not required.

After re-reading https://mbroz.fedorapeople.org/libcryptsetup_API/gcrypt_keyslot_maxroup__crypt-keyslot.html#gaf4ab92559b609c3aa7a34a2f3e22bee2

It does not make sense (to me) for cryptsetup supports LUKS2 but with zero keys. (in testing it always returns 32)

I added a specific error messaged for this.
const std::string instead and below (string_view would still make a copy at open)

yeah, it has to copy to make the c_string.
It is now a "static constexpr char"
We should just use ASSERT that this is not false instead and below

This is Wedig's pattern. It is more verbose, but prints a specific error message.

(https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/estoraged/+/refs/heads/master/src/test/estoraged_test.cpp#119)

The use case looks the same. If we don't like this I can change in both places.
These are reused a bunch of times, should we make a TEST_F instead and make these calls in the constructor instead?
Do we need these new header includes

estoraged_test ( yes for MockCryptsetupInterface, MockFilesystemInterface... )
cryptErase (not removed)
cryptsetupInterface (no removed)
estoraged ( yes for eStoraged object)
filesystemInterface ( no )
unistd (yes for the uint8_t)
sdbusplus/bus (no )
sdbusplus/server/object.hpp ( ?)
sdbusplus/test/sdbus_mock.hpp (yes for sdbusMock)
xyz/openbmc_project/Common/error.hpp (yes for errors::*)
xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Volume/client (for volumes::ext4)
xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Volume/server.hpp (no) 

done.
Thinking it might makes sense to be declared in this file (as noted in a previous comment)

It was here and we moved it to avoid the relative path.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/50394/7..11/src/test/meson.build#b12

I will open re open wedigs comment when it was there.
minor not: looks like "around" got missed here.
Do we actually want to fail? It sounded like getting 0 means it was already zeroed - would it make more sense to just exit this gracefully (maybe with just the error logs?)
Also, might be worth testing this special / corner case

I wrote and thought "0 means it was already zeroed" that earlier.
But that is not the case. Even after zeroed the MAX keyslots should stay the same. 

Maxkeyslots being zero is different then having no working keyslots.
If zero is returned by maxkeyslots, something is very wrong.

test added
